channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DATAJPA-793] Spring Boot has broken custom repository methods in Spring Data JPA
item.description:
We have working code with normal Spring 4.1.6.RELEASE. I've spent some time converting the project to use Spring Boot, which I really want to use, but Spring Boot has somehow broken the documented behaviour described here: https://docs.spring.io/spring-data/jpa/docs/current/reference/html/#repositories.custom-behaviour-for-all-repositories. The custom methods used on our repository base class are now getting reported as "property not found on entity <T>.

I've struggled all day to try to find a way around this, but have come up empty handed. Because the main property affected is a secondary id property (the entity ids are longs and the secondary id is a string) I figured I can use AttributeConverter on the entity base class to convert the @Id column from string to long, but alas, this doesn't work either because this mechanism doesn't support @Id columns. Very frustrating because that would have been immensely useful.

So, now I don't know how to get around this. I appreciate this bug may take time fix, so if anyone can tell me how to re-implement the custom methods in the meantime, I'd appreciate it.
item.summary: Spring Boot has broken custom repository methods in Spring Data JPA

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
It turns out that this issue was related to missing repository factory beans as well as the change of the interface of the JpaRepositoryFactory, as well as the lack of documentation relating to how to set this up.

I have it working now and it can be closed.

Looks like you're running into the same issue as I seem to have discovered for DATAJPA-794? Can you confirm? Great to hear you got it working, I'd still love to fix the docs and just want to make sure that fix would've helped you as well.

This is what I ended up with:

/**
 
 * This will replace the default {@link JpaRepositoryFactoryBean} and will
 
 * produce a custom {@link JpaRepositoryFactory}. It will provide the
 
 * {@link BaseRepositoryImpl} as the implementation of any interfaces that
 
 * extends the {@link JpaRepository} interface.
 
 *
 
 * @param <T> The type of the repository e.g {@link CrudRepository},
 
 *               {@link PagingAndSortingRepository}, {@link JpaRepository}.
 
 * @param <S> The domain type to be managed by the repository.
 
 */
 
public class BaseRepositoryFactoryBean<T extends JpaRepository<S, Long>, S extends Createable> extends
 
        JpaRepositoryFactoryBean<T, S, Long> {
 
 
 
    /**
 
     * Creates and returns {@link BaseRepositoryFactory}.
 
     */
 
    @SuppressWarnings("rawtypes")
 
    @Override
 
    protected RepositoryFactorySupport createRepositoryFactory(EntityManager entityManager) {
 
        return new BaseRepositoryFactory(entityManager);
 
    }
 
 
 
    /**
 
     * The repository factory class.
 
     *
 
     * @param <T> The domain type to be managed by the repository
 
     */
 
    private static class BaseRepositoryFactory<T extends Createable> extends JpaRepositoryFactory {
 
 
 
        /**
 
         * The EntityManager to be used.
 
         */
 
        private EntityManager entityManager;
 
 
 
        public BaseRepositoryFactory(EntityManager entityManager) {
 
            super(entityManager);
 
            this.entityManager = entityManager;
 
        }
 
 
 
        /**
 
         * Returns the repository implementation class {@link BaseRepositoryImpl}.
 
         */
 
        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
 
        @Override
 
        protected Object getTargetRepository(RepositoryInformation metadata) {
 
            return new BaseRepositoryImpl<T>((Class<T>) metadata.getDomainType(), entityManager);
 
        }
 
 
 
        /**
 
         * Returns the repository implementation class {@link BaseRepositoryImpl}.
 
         */
 
        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
 
        @Override
 
        protected <Z, ID extends Serializable> SimpleJpaRepository<?, ?> getTargetRepository(RepositoryInformation metadata, EntityManager entityManager) {
 
            return new BaseRepositoryImpl<T>((Class<T>) metadata.getDomainType(), entityManager);
 
        }
 
 
 
        /**
 
         * Returns the base class {@link BaseRepository}.
 
         */
 
        @Override
 
        protected Class<?> getRepositoryBaseClass(RepositoryMetadata metadata) {
 
            return BaseRepository.class;
 
        }
 
    }
 
}

If you switch the constructor of BaseRepositoryImpl to take a JpaEntityInformation and EntityManager instead, you should be able to get rid of all the factory implementations if you just rather configure @EnableJpaRepository(repositoryBaseClass = BaseRepositoryImpl.class).
Thanks, I'll pass that onto the other developers to look at. We're planning a general code cleanup and can look at it then.
Awesome! I'll make sure we update the documentation to show the correct constructor ASAP.
